lesson: July 4th is the 185th day of the year or 186th in leap years in the Gregorian calendar. There are 180 days remaining until the end of the year. Aphelion, the point during the orbit of the Earth when it is furthest from the Sun, occurs around this date.

lesson: Wild dogs travel in groups called packs. These packs are very social, working together to hunt, raise pups, and share food. They have been known to take care of sick or injured pack members. lesson: The c^2 in the equation stands for the speed of light squared. To square something means to multiply it by itself. The speed of light is approximately 3 * 10^8. If we square this, we get 9 * 10^16 meters^2/seconds^2 or to 90,000,000,000,000,000 meters^2/seconds^2.
title: Math

lesson: A mention (also known as @replies or tagging, not to be confused with metadata tags or hashtags #) is a means by which a blog post references or links to a user profile. This may be done as a matter of getting the attention of (or drawing attention to) another user of a social networking or blogging service.
title: Mention

lesson: Dogs have lived with people for at least 30,000 years. Dogs can serve people in many ways. For example, there are guard dogs, hunting dogs, herding dogs, and guide dogs for blind people.
title: Play: Bottom Row

lesson: Tigers vary in size depending on their subspecies. Siberian tigers are the largest. Males can grow to be 6 feet (1.8 meters) long (body length) and weigh about 500 pounds (230 kg). Females are a bit smaller. The record weight for males is claimed to be 700 pounds (318 kg), but this cannot be confirmed.
title: Tigers

lesson: Most natural diamonds are formed at high temperature and pressure at depths of 140 to 190 kilometers (87 to 118 mi) in the mantle of the Earth. Minerals containing carbon provide the carbon source, and the growth occurs over periods from 1 billion to 3.3 billion years (25% to 75% of the age of the Earth).
title: Natural Diamonds

lesson: Canada is the second largest country in the world by total area (Russia is the largest). It features the longest coastline in the world, stretching 202080 kilometers (125570 miles). Canada shares the longest land border in the world with the United States, totaling 8891 kilometers (5525 miles).
title: Canada

lesson: Fully autonomous vehicles (driverless cars) currently exist in prototype (Google has developed a driverless car). These cars are expected to be available commercially in the near future. title: Driverless Cars

lesson: Scandinavia is a geographical and cultural region in Northern Europe, which consists of Norway, Sweden, and Denmark. There is a completely different language spoken in each country (Norwegian, Danish, and Swedish). However, all three languages have Germanic roots and are considered mutually understandable.
title: Scandinavia

lesson: Air is the clear gas which living things breathe. It has no color or smell. The air around us is a mixture of many gases and dust particles. It is a mixture of about 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 0.9% argon, 0.04% carbon dioxide, and very small amounts of other gases. There is also an average of about 1% water vapor.
title: Air

lesson: France is the third largest country by size in Europe at 248,573 m2 (643,801 km2). The highest point in France is Mont Blanc at 15,771 feet (4,807 m) high, which is also one of the highest points in Europe. The greatest symbol of the country, the Eiffel Tower, was going to be demolished in 1909, but luckily was repurposed as a radio antenna.
title: France

lesson: A hashtag, written with a # symbol, is used to index keywords or topics on Twitter. This function was created on Twitter, and allows people to easily follow topics they are interested in. lesson: France is the birthplace of crepes. On almost every street corner you can find a small kiosk serving crepes. The aroma around crepe shops is so good that it is difficult to pass by without stopping to get a bite.

Writing this way saved time, with one letter flowing seamlessly into the next; a form of cursive writing.
title: Ampersand

lesson: Coconuts come from the coconut palm tree which grows throughout the tropics and subtropics. The coconut palm (Cocos nucifera) can grow up to 30 m (98 ft) tall and the leaf fronds can grow to be 4 to 6 m (13.1 to 19.7 ft) long. Coconut milk has a high fat content of around 17%, but is low in sugar.
title: Coconut

lesson: Costa Rica only takes up 0.03% of the surface of the planet but holds 5% of its biodiversity! There are over 130 species of fish, 220 species of reptiles, 1,000 species of butterflies, 9,000 species of plants, 20,000 species of spiders, and 34,000 species of insects! More than 25% of Costa Rican land is protected national parks and refuges.
title: Costa Rica

lesson: The makeup of our bodies changes as we age. The proportion of muscle decreases, and the proportion of body fat increases. title: Metabolism

lesson: Country music has its roots and beginnings in folk music. The old cowboy and pioneer songs of the American frontier were popular in the early twentieth century, and so were arrangements of pop music songs by rural (or rural sounding) performers. Country musicians also adapted new musical instruments, like the Hawaiian steel guitar.
title: Country Music

lesson: Formal education is usually in school, where a person may learn basic, academic, or trade skills. Small children often attend a nursery school or kindergarten but often formal education begins in elementary school and continues with secondary school. Post secondary education (or higher education) is usually at a college or university.
title: Formal Education

lesson: Frogs are amphibians of the order Anura. There is no fundamental difference between frogs and toads, and they are not classified separately. The toad form has evolved a number of times independently, an example of convergent evolution.
title: Frogs

lesson: During the eclipse of 2017, the Moon's shadow raced over the Earth's surface at more than 2,000 miles per hour. A roughly 65-mile-wide zone, called the path of totality, offered the best viewing. Stars and planets came out, and the Sun's corona glowed in a perfect circle around the dark side of the Moon.
title: Eclipse of 2017

lesson: Thomas Jefferson, the third of ten children, was born on April 13, 1743 in Shadwell, Virginia into a planter family. His parents were Peter and Jane Jefferson. He had six sisters and three brothers. At 9 years old Jefferson began studying Latin, Greek, and French; he also learned to ride horses, and began to study nature.
title: Thomas Jefferson

lesson: Food allergies are fairly common amongst adults and even more so among children. Around 2% of adults and 8% of children suffer from some type of food allergy where the immune system makes a mistake and thinks a certain food protein is dangerous and attacks it. Common food allergies are to seafood and peanuts.
title: Food Allergies

lesson: In 2017, the mainland U.S. will experience its first solar eclipse in almost 30 years. At the time of writing, the eclipse is scheduled to occur on August 21, 2017. Some are calling it the Great American Eclipse because the moon's shadow will cross twelve states from Oregon in the Pacific Northwest to South Carolina in the Southeast.
title: Great Eclipse

lesson: The timing of the Great Depression varied across nations, but in most countries it started in 1929 and lasted until the late 1930s or early 1940s. It was the longest, most widespread, and deepest depression of the 20th century. In the 21st century, the Great Depression is commonly used as an example of how far the world's economy can decline.
title: Great Depression

lesson: The four outer planets, or gas giants, collectively make up 99% of the mass known to orbit the Sun. Jupiter and Saturn are each many tens of times the mass of the Earth and consist overwhelmingly of hydrogen and helium. Uranus and Neptune are far less massive (<20 Earth masses) and possess more ice in their makeup.

lesson: When humans burn fossil fuels like gas and oil, a gas called carbon dioxide is released into the air. There, it reacts with water vapor. Some of the carbon falls back to Earth as rain. lesson: Cars with diesel engines tend to have better fuel economy, which means they can travel further on a single tank of gas. The drawback is that diesel engines emit gases called oxides of nitrogen, which pollute the environment. NOx can lead to acid rain, smog, and ozone. High levels of NOx in the atmosphere can make it hard to breathe.
title: Diesel Engines

lesson: Fathers are more involved in their children's lives today than in the past, says a new report from the American Academy of Pediatrics. It draws on census data, surveys, and academic research. Among the findings, the number of stay-at-home dads has increased by more than 60%. There were 98,000 in 2003 and 159,000 in 2012, according to the U.S. Census.
title: Stay-at-home Dads

lesson: In Mexico, bird habitats have been destroyed as forests and trees have been cut down to make room for farms and ranches. lesson: In 1776, colonists from Spain established a fort at the Golden Gate and a mission named for Francis of Assisi. The California Gold Rush of 1849 propelled the city into a period of rapid growth, increasing the population in one year from 1,000 to 25,000, and thus transforming it into the largest city on the West Coast at the time.
title: Gold Rush

lesson: Pluto is the 2nd most massive known dwarf planet in the solar system and the 10th most massive body observed directly orbiting the Sun. Originally classified as the 9th planet from the Sun, Pluto was recategorized as a dwarf planet and plutoid due to the discovery that it is 1 of many large bodies in the newly charted Kuiper belt.
title: Pluto

The government of Mexico actively promotes shared cultural traits in order to create a national identity.
title: Mexico

lesson: The Moon is in synchronous rotation with Earth. This means it always shows Earth the same face with its near side marked by dark volcanic maria that fills the spaces between the crustal highlands and impact craters. It is the brightest object in the sky after the Sun, although its surface is actually dark.
title: The Moon

lesson: The word oil is used for many different kinds of liquids. Oil usually does not mix with water. Some oils are made from plants and used in foods and for cooking. Some varieties of plant oils are African palm, maize (corn), olive, peanut, soy, and sunflower. Other kinds of oil are made from crude oil (petroleum) which comes from under the ground.
title: Oil

lesson: Plants take water from soil through their veins, which are called xylem. The water goes to their leaves, which take carbon dioxide from the air. Carbon dioxide mixes with the water. Energy from the sun helps this process along and turns the combination into a sugar called glucose. Glucose is plant food, it gives plants energy to grow.
title: Life of Plants

Not having enough can lead to iron deficiency and symptoms such as weakness and fatigue.

lesson: Persians invented a type of evaporative cooler known as a Yakhchal around 400 BCE. It was a dome-shaped object used as a means of refrigeration. The items meant to be kept cool were stored in the subterranean part of this structure and since it had this subterranean space as well as heat-resistant materials, it was capable of storing ice or foods in the hot desert year-round.
title: Refrigeration

lesson: Muhammad Ali, the three time world heavyweight boxing champion, never forgot his roots. He returned to his old neighborhood and visited high school classmates even after becoming one of the most recognizable men in the world. Muhammad Ali was born and raised in Kentucky, where he started boxing at the age of 12.
title: Muhammad Ali

title: Australia

lesson: Robots have many uses. Factories use industrial robots to do hard work quickly and without mistakes. The military uses robots to find and get rid of bombs. If a mistake is made on a battlefield, the robot is damaged or destroyed, which is better than a person being killed. There are also domestic robots that can vacuum or cut grass.
title: Robots

lesson: A windmill converts the energy of the wind into rotational energy. Wind power stations use the wind to turn a turbine which turns a magnet inside a coil. The wind has kinetic energy (movement energy) which is changed into mechanical energy by the blades on the turbine. The turbine then turns a generator which creates electrical energy (voltage).
title: Windmills

lesson: China has the world's oldest continuous civilization. There is archaeological evidence of this that is over 5,000 years old. China also has one of the world's oldest writing systems, and is viewed as the source of many major inventions. China is home to some of the oldest artwork in the world. Statues and pottery are some classic examples.
title: Ancient China

lesson: The four farthest planets in the solar system, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, are called gas giants. This is because they are large planets that are mostly made of gas, such as hydrogen and helium, with a relatively small rocky core. Even though they are made of gas, they have significantly more mass than the terrestrial planets.
title: Gas Giants

lesson: Water is a molecule made of 2 hydrogen atoms and 1 oxygen atom. Its chemical formula is H2O. Water has surface tension, so a little bit of water makes drops rather than spreading out over the surface. Though a human being can survive for up to a week without food, they can only survive for a day or two without water.
title: Water

lesson: When you do research, always remember to write down the places you find information. This is called citing, or making a citation. A good idea is to bookmark all of the pages with information you want to use so you don't lose track of your sources. Then, when you are ready to make your bibliography, you'll be prepared.
title: Citation

lesson: Although we think of our Sun as a unique celestial body, it is actually one of trillions of stars in the universe. Some estimates for stars similar to the Sun in just the Milky Way galaxy are as high as 7 billion. If this number is correct, there could be over one trillion stars that are roughly the same as our Sun in the universe.
title: The Sun

lesson: A black hole is a region of spacetime from which nothing, not even light, can escape. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass will deform spacetime to form a black hole. Most black holes are made when a supergiant star dies.

lesson: How much time do you spend thinking about the communities you belong to? If you're like most of us, probably not enough. That's because we take them for granted. Whether it's our circle of friends, the clubs we've joined or even the sports teams we play for, we tend to forget we belong to many different communities at the same time.
title: Your Communities

title: Marie Curie

lesson: While there are hundreds of thousands of known marine life forms, there are many that are yet to be discovered. title: Marine Life

lesson: A river is a stream of water that flows through a "channel" (or passage) in the surface of the ground. A river begins on high ground or in hills or mountains and flows down from the high ground to the lower ground due to gravity.

title: Indonesia

title: Pocket Monsters

lesson: California is a big power in American culture as well as the business life of the nation. Many of the great changes in technology and law came from California, and the state pays more to the U.S. government than it gets back. It also has some of the country's largest cities, such as Los Angeles, San Diego, San Jose, and San Francisco.
title: California

lesson: Drone flights will be permitted only during the day and at twilight. Drone industry officials have long complained that these time restrictions precluded a great many uses. Among them are some search and rescue operations. Some agricultural operations are best done after dark as well. Operators can seek waivers to many of these restrictions.
title: Drones

lesson: A tree is a tall plant with a trunk and branches made of wood. It can live for many years. The four main parts of a tree are the roots, the trunk, the branches, and the leaves. A single tree has many roots. The roots of a tree are usually underground. One case for which this is not true are the roots of the mangrove tree.
title: Parts of Trees

lesson: "The most difficult thing is the decision to act, the rest is merely tenacity." Amelia Earhart was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. In 1937, Earhart disappeared over the central Pacific Ocean near Howland Island when attempting to make a circumnavigational flight around the globe.
title: Amelia Earhart

lesson: Alexander Graham Bell was the first person to patent the telephone, in 1876. Early telephones were wired directly to each other and could only talk to the phone that they were connected to. Later, telephone exchanges allowed connecting to other telephones. During the 20th century the machines that made the connections were automated.
title: Telephone

lesson: The Korean alphabet, also known as Hangul, is the native alphabet of the Korean language. It was created by Sejong the Great during the Joseon Dynasty in 1443, and is now the official script of both South Korea and North Korea. There are 14 basic consonants and 10 basic vowels. Letters that have similar sounds also have similar shapes.
title: Korean Language

lesson: Seawater cannot be drunk safely because it has high salinity, or concentration of salt. Seawater is also called salt water. Both people and animals often live near rivers, because they need water to survive. The water in a river is called fresh water. Fresh water comes from rain or snow and it can usually be drunk safely, unless it has been polluted.
title: Seawater

lesson: Birds are found on every continent of the world. Birds of different types can live in freezing cold environments, and others can live in hot deserts. Birds live in forests, in grasslands, on cliff faces, in river banks, on stony seashores, down mine shafts, and under the roofs of houses.
title: Birds

lesson: "Life is what happens to you while you're busy making other plans." John Lennon was an English singer & songwriter, and one of the founders of the Beatles. The Beatles were one of the most influential bands of their time. Lennon also had a solo career with such famous songs as "Imagine" and "Give Peace a Chance".
title: John Lennon

lesson: Walt Disney worked very hard to run his movie studio. He liked to spend weekends with his two daughters. The family liked going to carnivals and fairs. Mr. Disney wanted to build a place that had all of the fun of the traveling fairs where parents and children could ride together. That is how Mr. Disney got the idea for Disneyland.
title: Walt Disney

lesson: One famous attraction of Indiana is the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, which is where the Indy 500 is held every year. The Indy 500 is one of the most famous car races in the United States. The Indianapolis Motor Speedway is not actually in Indianapolis. It is in a town called Speedway, which is completely surrounded by Indianapolis.
title: Indy 500

lesson: At first, Washington D.C. was made up of a piece of Virginia located south of the Potomac River and a piece of Maryland located north of the Potomac River. In 1847, Virginia's land was returned to it. This area is now part of Arlington County. Since 1847, all of Washington D.C. is on the north side of the Potomac River.
title: Washington D.C.

lesson: In the United States, the presidential election is held every four years on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November. You help choose your state's electors when you vote for President because when you vote for your candidate you are actually voting for your candidate's electors. This is part of a system called the Electoral College.
title: Election

lesson: "Whether you think you can or you think you can't, you're right." Henry Ford was an American industrialist, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, and the sponsor of the development of the assembly line technique of mass production. Ford developed and manufactured the first automobile that many middle-class Americans could afford.
title: Henry Ford

lesson: wood Drone branches busy Piece attraction Florida states important Business life safely culture years Seawater Disney spend South famous
title: Play: Words

lesson: The United States Constitution makes the President the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and lists powers given to the president. George Washington was the first President of the United States from 1789 to 1797. He was also the commander in chief of all American forces during the American Revolutionary War.
title: U.S. Constitution

lesson: The Moon appears to have more craters and scars than Earth because it has a lot less natural activity. The Earth is constantly reforming its surface through earthquakes, erosion, rain, wind, and plants growing on the surface. The Moon, however, has very little weather or activity that would alter its appearance.
title: Moon's Surface

lesson: A library is not a bookstore (a store that sells books). Many places have a public library, where anybody can join if they live in the area. With a library card, people can borrow books and take them home for several weeks. It does not cost money to get a library card at most public libraries.
title: Library

lesson: Thailand has been raising and training pigtailed macaques, a species of monkey common to the area, to pick coconuts for around 400 years. Coconut farmers in Sri Lanka, Malaysia, India and other countries in the region sometimes rely on monkeys, too. The monkeys attend a training school where they learn to pick coconuts.
title: Coconut Pickers

lesson: "Go confidently in the direction of your dreams. Live the life you have imagined." Henry David Thoreau was a 19th century American essayist, poet, and philosopher. Among his lasting contributions are his writings on natural history and philosophy, in which he anticipated the methods and findings of ecology and environmental history.
title: Thoreau

lesson: Recycling is turning the materials from trash into something new. Glass, paper, plastic, and metals such as aluminum and steel are all commonly recycled. Dead plants and some kitchen trash can be recycled through composting. Recycling is different than reusing, which is where old things, such as clothes, are donated or given a new use instead of being thrown out.
title: Recycling

lesson: There are two species in the Delphinus genus, the Short-beaked Common Dolphin (Delphinus delphis), and the Long-beaked Common Dolphin (Delphinus capensis). Some studies say there is a third species, the "Arabian Common Dolphin" (Delphinus tropicalis), which has a long, thin beak and is found in the Indian Ocean and the Red Sea.
title: Dolphins

lesson: The first Disneyland opened on July 17, 1955. It is one of the most popular theme parks in the world. Disneyland celebrated its golden anniversary on July 17, 2005. In 2001, the area around the park expanded into a resort with 3 hotels, a shopping and dining area called Downtown Disney and a second theme park, Disney's California Adventure.
title: Disneyland

lesson: Recycling reduces the amount of raw materials and energy used to make things. Most of the time, it takes less energy to recycle trash than to throw it away, The Economist says. Recycling helps minimize the amount of garbage that ends up in trash dumps around the world.
title: Reasons to Recycle

lesson: A light year is the distance that light travels through empty space in one year. Since the speed of light is about 300,000 km per second (about 186,000 miles per second), then one light year is about 10 trillion kilometers (about 6 trillion miles). A light year is not a length of time. Light years are used in astronomy because the universe is huge.
title: Light Year

lesson: Few countries with "free speech" let everything be said. For example, the U.S. Supreme Court said that it is against the law to shout "fire" in a crowded theater if there is no fire because it might cause people to panic. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights also says that it is not okay to cause national, racial, or religious hatred.
title: Freedom of Speech

lesson: In the center of southern Florida is a very big lake called Lake Okeechobee. It is the seventh largest freshwater lake in the United States and the second largest freshwater lake entirely within the lower 48 states. Okeechobee is 730 square miles, about half the size of the state of Rhode Island, and is very shallow for a lake of its size.
title: Lake Okeechobee

lesson: Romeo and Juliet is one of the most famous plays written by William Shakespeare. It tells a story of two young people who love each other eternally, but have to overcome numerous obstacles to be together. They both come from noble families, however, the Capulets and the Montagues are mortal enemies. The story is set in the beautiful Italian city of Verona.
title: Romeo and Juliet

lesson: There are dogs that are trained to smell for diseases in the human body or to find bombs or illegal drugs. These dogs sometimes help police in airports or other areas. Sniffer dogs (usually beagles) are sometimes trained for this job. Dogs have even been sent by Russians into outer space. The first dog sent to space was named Laika.
title: Police Dogs

lesson: "When one door closes, another door opens. But we so often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door, that we do not see the ones which open for us." A quote by Alexander Graham Bell, the brilliant scientist, inventor, and engineer credited with patenting the first telephone in 1876. He refused to have a telephone in his study.
title: Alexander G. Bell

lesson: "When one door closes, another door opens. But we so often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door, that we do not see the ones which open for us." A quote by Alexander Graham Bell
title: Placement Test More Symbols

lesson: Oliver Twist is Charles Dickens's second novel. It tells a story of an orphan boy who was captured by thieves and forced to work with them. The book is often referred to as a social novel, as it draws the reader's attention to child labor and the presence of orphan children on the streets.
title: Oliver Twist

lesson: Red pandas are native to the Himalayas and southwestern China. The English word for red panda is "Firefox" which is where the popular web browser gets its name from. Many people think that the Firefox logo is a fox, but the truth is that the logo is actually a red panda. The browser was created in 2002 and its full name is Mozilla Firefox.
title: Red Pandas

lesson: Marquette and Joliet are given credit for being the first Europeans to find the state of Illinois. Illinois became a state on December 3, 1818. Its state insect is the Monarch Butterfly, its state tree is the white oak, its state flower is the violet, its state bird is the cardinal, and its state animal is the white-tailed deer.
title: Illinois

lesson: Music is sound that has been organized using rhythm, melody, or harmony. If someone bangs saucepans while cooking, it makes noise. If a person bangs saucepans in a rhythmic way, they are making a simple type of music. Blues is played by singing, using the harmonica, or the acoustic guitar. Jazz musicians use instruments such as the trumpet and saxophone.
title: Music Structure

lesson: Climate is the average weather usually taken over a 30 year time period for a particular region and time period. Climate is not the same as weather, but rather, it is the average pattern of weather for a particular region. Weather describes the short-term state of the atmosphere, including temperature, precipitation, air pressure, and cloud cover.
title: Climate

lesson: Leo Tolstoy is a Russian author who wrote one of the most famous Russian novels in the history of literature called War and Peace. The book describes life in Russia in the 19th century during the wars with Napoleon. There are almost 600 characters mentioned in the story, but the main characters are members of 4 noble families.
title: War and Peace

lesson: Cave paintings are painted drawings on cave walls or ceilings, mainly of prehistoric origin. Evidence suggests that they were not merely decorations of living areas since the caves in which they have been found do not have signs of ongoing habitation. They are also often located in areas of caves that are not easily accessible.
title: Prehistoric Art

lesson: Almost as soon as automobiles were invented races of various sorts were organized, with the first recorded as early as 1867. Many of the earliest events were reliability trials, aimed at proving these new machines were a practical mode of transport. Soon, they became an important way for competing makers to demonstrate their machines.
title: Car Races

lesson: Martial arts are codified systems and traditions of combat practices, which are practiced for a variety of reasons including self-defense, military and law enforcement applications, and mental and spiritual development. In addition, they are practiced for entertainment and the preservation of a nation's intangible cultural heritage.
title: Martial Arts

lesson: Online communities are now a normal part of our everyday lives. The internet has not only changed the way we form communities, but the tools we use to communicate, too. People around the world use social media sites to keep in touch with family and meet new people, or connect with friends using online games on their phones or computers.
title: Communities

lesson: Music is found in every known culture, past and present, varying widely between times and places. Since all people of the world, including the most isolated tribal groups, have a form of music, it may be concluded that music is likely to have been present in the ancestral population prior to the dispersal of humans around the world.
title: Music Everywhere

lesson: Giant pandas are about the size of an American black bear. They are about 3 feet (91 cm) tall at the shoulder when they are standing on all four legs. Pandas are typically about 6 feet (180 cm) long. In the wild, males can weigh up to 250 pounds (110 kg). Females usually weigh less than 220 pounds (100 kg).
title: Pandas, Part 3

lesson: Some theories hold that cave paintings may have been a way of communicating with others, while other theories ascribe a religious or ceremonial purpose to them. The paintings are remarkably similar around the world, with animals being common subjects. Humans mainly appear as images of hands.
title: Cave Paintings

lesson: The prehistoric age is considered to have ended with the development of writing, and with it, by definition, prehistoric music. "Ancient music" is the name given to the music that followed. The oldest known song was written in cuneiform, dating to 3400 years ago from Ugarit. It was deciphered by Anne Draffkorn Kilmer.
title: Ancient Music

lesson: The area now called England was first inhabited by modern humans during the Upper Palaeolithic period, but it takes its name from the Angles, one of the Germanic tribes who settled the area during the 5th and 6th centuries. The term Anglo-Saxon stems from the Angles and the Saxons, another tribe that inhabited the area during that time.
title: Anglo-Saxons

lesson: Newton's second law of motion is: the resultant force is equal to mass times acceleration. This law says that acceleration is dependent on the forces acting upon an object and the mass of the object. Therefore if the force increases, acceleration increases, and the more mass the object has, the acceleration decreases.
title: Newton's Law

lesson: Health care is the preservation of mental and physical health by preventing or treating illnesses through services offered by the health profession and its staff. Health care includes all reasonable and necessary medical aid, medical evaluations, and medical services. The right to health care is considered a human right.
title: Health Care

lesson: The Industrial Revolution was a period from the 18th to the 19th century where major changes in agriculture, manufacturing, mining, transportation, and technology had a profound effect on the socioeconomic and cultural conditions of the times. It began in the United Kingdom, then spread throughout Europe, North America, and eventually the world.
title: Industry Awakes

lesson: When an electric charge builds up on the surface of an object it creates static electricity. You have probably experienced static electricity in the form of a small electric shock, which is what happens when an electric charge is quickly neutralized by an opposite charge. Opposite charges attract each other. Positive charges repel each other, as do negative charges.
title: Static Electricity

lesson: Words per minute (WPM) is a measure of input or output speed. For the purposes of WPM measurement, a word is standardized to five characters or keystrokes. The average person types around 40 words per minute. However, professional typists type a lot faster. On average, professional typists can type upwards of 65 to 80 WPM.
title: Words per Minute

lesson: The Divine Comedy is an epic poem written by Dante Alighieri. It is divided in three parts, with Inferno being the most famous one. The word "comedy" in the title does not mean that the poem is funny, rather that it has a positive ending. Dante has to travel through 9 concentric circles of suffering to be saved.
title: Divine Comedy

lesson: An elephant's trunk is able to sense the size, shape, and temperature of an object. An elephant uses its trunk like a human uses its hands. It can grab food and put it in its mouth to feed itself. It can also suck up water and pour it into its mouth or spray itself on a hot day. Elephants can use their trunks like a snorkel to breathe in deep water.
title: Elephant's Trunk

lesson: A healthy diet provides the body with essential nutrition: fluid, adequate essential amino acids from protein, essential fatty acids, vitamins, minerals, and adequate calories. The requirements for a healthy diet can be met from a variety of plant-based and animal-based foods.
title: Healthy Diet

lesson: Nefertiti was the primary wife of the Pharaoh Akhenaten, who unsuccessfully tried to change the religion of Egypt. Akhenaten was then succeeded by a pharaoh referred to as Smenkhare. Some scientists believe Smenkhare and Nefertiti are the same person. Many think the queen changed her name during her rule. She reigned during the wealthiest period of Ancient Egypt.
title: Nefertiti

lesson: Teachers direct the education of students and might draw on many subjects, including reading, writing, mathematics, science, and history. In many countries, teachers must obtain certifications or a university degree in order to qualify for a position. Teachers around the world work hard to help students learn.
title: Teachers

lesson: The basic unit of an element is called an atom. An atom is the smallest building block that you can cut an element into without the element breaking down into a lighter element. Two ways that atoms can be broken down are through nuclear fission or radioactive decay. A chemical compound is a substance made up of 2 or more elements.
title: Atoms

lesson: The Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions among representatives of city-states and one of the Panhellenic Games of Ancient Greece. They were held in honor of Zeus, and the Greeks gave them a mythological origin. The first Olympic Games were held in 776 BC, and they continued to be celebrated when Greece came to be under Roman rule.
title: Olympics History

lesson: During the celebration of the games, an Olympic Truce was enacted so that athletes could travel from their cities to the games in safety. The prizes for the victors were olive leaf wreaths or crowns. The games became a political tool used by city-states to assert dominance over their rivals. The Olympics also featured religious celebrations.
title: Olympics Ceremony

lesson: Genetically modified foods, or GMOs, are foods produced from organisms that have had changes introduced to their DNA using methods of genetic engineering. Genetic engineering techniques allow for the introduction of new traits as well as greater control over traits than previous methods such as selective breeding and mutation breeding.
title: GM Foods

lesson: "I've missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times I've been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed." Michael Jordan is a retired professional basketball player. He played 15 seasons with the Bulls and Wizards.
title: Michael Jordan

lesson: Jordan olympic Message comedy Source remember Track information essential Banker person healthy Electronic material Game celebration
title: Play: Words

lesson: There are eight planets in the solar system. From closest to farthest from the Sun, they are: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. A fun way to remember the order of the planets is to use a mnemonic device: My Very Excellent Mother Just Served Us Noodles. Each letter represents the name of one planet.
title: Our Solar System

lesson: A volcano is an opening, typically a mountain, in the Earth's surface that opens downward to a pool of hot liquid rock, or magma. When pressure builds up underneath the volcano, eruptions can occur. When a volcano erupts, gas, ash, and magma can shoot through the opening. When magma leaves a volcano, it is known as lava.
title: Volcano

lesson: Frogs can live on land and in fresh water. They cannot survive in salt water. Their development is by metamorphosis. They hatch from eggs as tadpoles, which are laid by a female frog. The eggs are called frogspawn. Tadpoles have tails and gills. When they grow up, they lose their tails and gills and grow four long legs.
title: Frogs

lesson: Australia is a country in the Southern Hemisphere between the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean. Its official name is the Commonwealth of Australia. Australia is the sixth biggest country in the world by landmass. The Australian emblem is a flower called the Golden Wattle. Australia is also the smallest continent in the world.
title: Australia

lesson: When Japanese meet, they traditionally bow instead of shake hands. The lower the bow, the deeper respect it shows. Sumo is recognized as the national sport of Japan, although it isn't the most popular one. Sumo is a wrestling sport where a wrestler tries to force another wrestler out of a circular ring. Sumo is practiced professionally in Japan.
title: Japan

lesson: The benefits of exercise for all ages have been known since antiquity. Marcus Cicero, around 65 BC, stated, "It is exercise alone that supports the spirits, and keeps the mind in vigor." Regular exercise has been shown to help high blood pressure, obesity, heart disease, diabetes, and depression, among other conditions.
title: Exercise

lesson: There are many other systems like our solar system in the universe. Each star has the potential to have a planetary system. There are more than 200 billion stars in the Milky Way galaxy. The Sun is the star found at the center of our solar system. At around 1,392,000 kilometers (865,000 miles) wide, the Sun's diameter is about 110 times wider than Earth's.
title: Milky Way

lesson: "Rock bottom became the solid foundation on which I rebuilt my life." J.K. Rowling is a British novelist and screenwriter. She is best known as the author of the very popular fantasy book series Harry Potter. The Harry Potter book series consists of 7 books, which were turned into 8 movies.
title: J.K. Rowling

lesson: Over the years, the web has grown bigger and bigger. Today, there are tens of trillions of pages on the Internet. That's so many pages that if you were to print them out and stack them all, you would have a pile that would reach from Earth to the Moon at least a dozen times. All of these pages are connected to each other through links.
title: Internet Size

lesson: The general concept of human posture refers to the "carriage of the body as a whole, the attitude of the body, or the position of the limbs." Good posture helps improve our concentration, letting us work longer and harder. It also prevents sore muscles, leading us to feel happier and healthier both at and away from the computer.
title: Human Posture

lesson: Italy is a country in Europe and one of the founding countries of the European Union. It is a peninsula located in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea. Thanks to its shape, it is often referred to as the Boot. Italy is said to have more masterpieces per square mile than any other country. Italy's capital, Rome, is home to the famous Colosseum.
title: Italy

lesson: Some studies suggest that people tend to read as much as 10% slower from a screen than from paper. Reading text from a computer screen can negatively impact your vision in the long term. The blue light emitted from devices such as computers or mobile phones has been proven to diminish the quality of sleep and cause headaches.
title: Reading Speed

lesson: New Mexico is a state in the United States of America. It is part of the American Southwest and is bordered by Texas to the east, Oklahoma to the northeast, Colorado to the north, and Arizona to the west. The northwest corner of the state also touches Utah. This area is known as the Four Corners because four states meet there.
title: New Mexico

lesson: A modern notification system is a combination of software and hardware that provides a means of delivering a message to a set of recipients. For example, notification systems can send an email when a new topic has been added to Wikipedia.
title: Notifications

lesson: There are 50 states in the United States of America, with Hawaii being the last one to join in 1959. There are independent US territories believed to be part of the 50 states, such as Puerto Rico and Guam, which is a very common misconception. They are self governing territories with locally elected governors and territorial legislatures.
title: US Territories

lesson: document Survive apple system Posture general Notification combination Software hardware Today benefit Pacific ocean Water salt Frog website
title: Play: Words

lesson: Plants and animals (including people) are mostly water inside. The human body is made up of 60% to 70% water. All plants and animals need water to live. Water gives a medium for chemical reactions to take place, and is the main part of blood. Water helps blood carry nutrients from the stomach to all parts of the body to keep the body alive.
title: Power of Water

lesson: Here is a quick recipe for staying healthy: take a break every 15 minutes to give your eyes and body a rest! Get out of your chair; maybe even take a short walk. If you have a window in the room, take a look outside. Stretch your back, neck, and arms, and reach for the sky. Take a break, get active, and stay healthy!
title: Stay Healthy

lesson: Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus was the first scientist to suggest that the Earth was not the center of the universe. He proposed a model that placed the Sun in the center in his publication in 1543. It is said that Copernicus did not want to publish his theses for fear of the reaction he would receive.
title: Copernicus

lesson: Dogs can smell and hear very well, but cannot see colors very well. Dogs are sometimes referred to as "man's best friend" because they are kept as domestic pets, are usually loyal, and like being around humans. Dogs can be taught many skills and often have jobs helping people, such as service dogs, guard dogs, and police dogs.
title: Man's Best Friend

lesson: Little Women is a book by Louisa May Alcott published in 1868. The story is about the fictional March sisters, who lived in the time of the American Civil War. Their father served as a chaplain in the Union Army. The author was inspired by her own childhood experiences when writing the book. The book was made into a drama film in 1994.
title: Little Women

lesson: Most social media sites share some of the basics. You create a profile which tells other users who you are. You get to pick an avatar, your online likeness in the form of a picture or drawing. You'll probably meet trolls, or people who are there to annoy others. You'll have tools to flag or report inconsiderate and improper content.
title: Social Media I

lesson: A dental hygienist is a dental professional registered with a dental association in their country. Dental hygienists often work alongside dentists to provide full oral health care. Very few dental hygienists work independently. Their training focuses on the prevention and treatment of oral disease, such as cavities, gum disease etc.
title: Dental Hygienist

lesson: Mr. Disney's friends thought the idea of making an amusement park was a crazy one. After selling land that he loved very much in Palm Springs to help pay for the park, the building of Disneyland began in 1954. He also used a weekly television show called Disneyland to make people want to see his park. In only one year, Disneyland Park was open.
title: Disneyland Park

lesson: Some birds that eat mainly seeds feed their young on insects. A few types of birds eat green plants, but only one species lives on leaves. Hummingbirds and Honeyeaters live on the nectar or honey in flowers. Birds come in many sizes from the Bee Hummingbird that is only 60 mm long to the ostrich which stands 2.5 meters high.
title: Hummingbirds

lesson: A flame is the visible, gaseous part of a fire. A flame is a mixture of reacting gases and solids emitting visible, infrared, and sometimes ultraviolet light. The frequency spectrum of the emitted light depends on the chemical composition of the burning material, or fuel, and the intermediate reaction products.
title: Flame

lesson: Healing arts programs began at a handful of hospitals in the 1960s but have skyrocketed in the past decade or so. Research has shown that art can be therapeutic for people during stressful times. A 2015 Review: of past studies in The Lancet found that listening to music before, during or after surgery helped recovery.
title: Healing Arts

lesson: The earliest maps were probably simple sketches in dirt. Eventually, ancient people began to carve maps on stone and clay tablets. The oldest surviving clay map, dated to around 2,300 B.C., comes from ancient Mesopotamia. Other ancient maps have been found around the world. These were typically focused on the area around the map-makers and did not attempt to map the whole Earth.
title: Maps

lesson: There are many different types of social media. The most common are personal networks like Facebook, where you connect with other people. There are media sharing sites like Instagram where you post pictures. There are also forums, where people meet to chat about specific topics, and social publishing, like KidBlog where you post longer articles.
title: Social Media II

lesson: Nursing is an extremely popular profession in the United States, with around 3 million registered nurses nationwide. Nurses provide care and support for individuals and their families. They work alongside physicians and follow their directions precisely to ensure a quick recovery of each patient. Their ultimate goal is to improve our quality of life.
title: Nursing

lesson: While relatively small quantities of water are observed by humans to be colorless, pure water has a slight blue color. The blue tint of water is an intrinsic property and is caused by selective absorption and scattering of white light. Impurities dissolved or suspended in water may give water different colored appearances.
title: Pure Water
